result.rationale: Laubuka trevori is assessed as Vulnerable since it has a restricted distribution in Cauvery River system in Karnataka and in Kerala, India with an Extent of Occurrence of  less than 20,000 km2 and is currently known from three locations where the habitat is threatened by modifications because of anthropogenic activities including deforestation for developmental activities, severe loss of riparian habitat, expansions of agricultural lands, pesticide contamination from agricultural runoff and sand mining. Destructive fishing practices, including dynamite fishing, are also common. Further, the populations could also be threatened by non-native species of fishes. Massive floods in Kerala caused by anthropogenic activities, including climate change, led to drastic devastation in ecology of Wayanad and Coorg areas and could have affected the habitat of the species in the past. It is therefore essential to note that the species is known only from its original description and research is needed to understand its population status, trends, distribution, ecology and species specific threats.
result.geographicrange: Laubuka trevori is at presently known from the Cauvery River system at Coorg (Kodagu) in Karnataka and Wayanad and Pookode in Kerala, India (Knight 2015, Thampy et al. 2021).
result.population: In Kabini river, Kerala, the species is very rare (Thampy et al. 2021). There is no information about the population status of the species from Coorg. There is no quantitative estimates regarding overall population trends for this species.
result.habitat: Laubuka trevori inhabits streams and rivers (Knight 2015, Thampy et al. 2021). The quality of habitat of the species is deteriorating because of deforestation, severe loss of riparian habitat, expansions of agricultural lands, pesticide contamination from agricultural runoff, destructive fishing practices, and sand mining (Sunil et al. 2010, 2016; Patil et al. 2015; Thampy et al. 2021).
result.threats: The habitat of Laubuka trevori is threatened by modification because of anthropogenic activities including deforestation for developmental activities, severe loss of riparian habitat, expansions of agricultural lands, pesticide contamination from agricultural runoff and sand mining (Sunil et al. 2010, 2016 Patil et al. 2015; Thampy et al. 2021). Destructive fishing practices, including dynamite fishing, are common (Thampy et al. 2021). Exotic species reported from the same locations where L. trevori was reported, including Clarias gariepinus, Cyprinus carpio, Poecilia reticulata, Xiphophorus helleri, Oreochromis mossambicus, Oreochromis niloticus, and Pterygoplichthys sp., are also likely to threat the species' population (Thampy et al. 2021). Massive floods in Kerala in 2018, because of several anthropogenic activities including climate change, caused drastic devastation in ecology of Wayanad and Coorg areas (Viju 2019) and might have adversely affected habitat of L. trevori.
result.conservationmeasures: No species-specific conservation actions are in place for Laubuka trevori. The species is also not known from any protected area. Because the habitat of the species is threatened there is a need for conservation of habitat and resources. Since the species is known only from its original description, research is also essential to understand its population status, trends, distribution, ecology and species specific threats. Monitoring the population and habitat trends is also essential.
result.usetrade: There is no information on use and trade of this species.
